citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult female Poodle named "Curly" had excessively matted hair along her back, on her tail, and down her back legs.
Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to provide protection from
the heat or cold. The licensee must remove the matted hair from this animal and must establish an effective program of
haircoat maintenance.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023.

The gravel in four outdoor enclosures housing a total of 10 adults and 5 puppies were entirely wet. All of the dogs were
wet and dirty from walking on the wet gravel and dirt. Wet and dirty dogs can be uncomfortable and may have difficulty
staying warm. The licensee must ensure that enclosures have enough gravel to allow adequate drainage and to keep the
dogs dry.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The outside pens of two enclosures of the sheltered building (housing a total of 4 adult dogs) had standing water. The
inside portion of one enclosure containing 3 adult dogs had an excessive amount of fecal material which had been
smashed flat from the dogs walking in it. Standing water and fecal material can contain microorganisms that can affect
the health of the dogs. The licensee must ensure that standing water is removed from the primary enclosures.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
An enclosure housing 3 adult dogs had excessive dirt and grime on the entire walls. The dogs currently inside the
enclosure were short and could not reach the top of the walls. The licensee stated that the enclosure previously
contained a large dog and that the enclosure had not been cleaned prior to the addition of the small dogs. Dirt and grime
can harbor diseases that can affect the health of the dogs. The licensee must clean and sanitize used primary enclosures
before they are used to house other dogs.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult female Poodle named "Curly" had excessively matted hair along her back, on her tail, and down her back legs.  
Matted hair can result in skin problems, can be painful, and can compromise the hair’s ability to provide protection from 
the heat or cold.   The licensee must remove the matted hair from this animal and must establish an effective program of 
haircoat maintenance. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023. 
3.6(a)(2)(v) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The gravel in four outdoor enclosures housing a total of 10 adults and 5 puppies were entirely wet.  All of the dogs were 
wet and dirty from walking on the wet gravel and dirt.  Wet and dirty dogs can be uncomfortable and may have difficulty 
staying warm.  The licensee must ensure that enclosures have enough gravel to allow adequate drainage and to keep the 
dogs dry. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023. 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

The outside pens of two enclosures of the sheltered building (housing a total of 4 adult dogs) had standing water.  The 
inside portion of one enclosure containing 3 adult dogs had an excessive amount of fecal material which had been 
smashed flat from the dogs walking in it.  Standing water and fecal material can contain microorganisms that can affect 
the health of the dogs.  The licensee must ensure that standing water is removed from the primary enclosures. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023. 
3.11(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
An enclosure housing 3 adult dogs had excessive dirt and grime on the entire walls.  The dogs currently inside the 
enclosure were short and could not reach the top of the walls.  The licensee stated that the enclosure previously 
contained a large dog and that the enclosure had not been cleaned prior to the addition of the small dogs.  Dirt and grime 
can harbor diseases that can affect the health of the dogs.  The licensee must clean and sanitize used primary enclosures 
before they are used to house other dogs. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MARCH 26, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
